page.title: 15FERRING cont.
page.content:
The celebrated miller John Olliver operated the mill on Highdown Hill in the l780's and was buried, some say, upside down, in his own altar tomb on the hillside (still to be seen today).
Revenue men fought with over 60 smugglers in Ferring in June 1720.
Ferring village is bounded to the north by the A259 and Highdown Hill, to the south by the sea, the east by Goring Gap(farmland) and to the west by the River Rife and the Rife lands (white land). The parish council of 15 councillors resist all attempts to build to the east and west of the village thus retaining its individuality and exclusiveness. Known as "north" and "south" Ferring, there are private estates at the sea end and council houses by the railway.
